translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Section of Sevens
The Heron Birth Story

analyzed: dvāsattati gotama puñña kammā  vasa vattinaḥ jāti jaram atītā
translated: “Seventy-two, Gotama, who have done meritorious deeds,🔽Who have control, who have passed beyond birth and old age,
This is the last time for the one who knows, the one who is holy, to be reborn,
Many people are worshipping me.”

original: “Appañhi etaṁ na hi dīghamāyu,🔽Yaṁ tvaṁ baka maññasi dīghamāyuṁ;
analyzed: etam na hi dīgham āyu  yam tvam baka maññasi dīgham āyu
translated: “This is little, it is not a long life,🔽That you think, heron, is a long life.
I know a life of a hundred thousand years without interruption,
I am the one who knows, O Brahmā.”

analyzed: ananta dassī bhagavān aham asmi  jātijjaram sokam upātivattaḥ
translated: “I am the one who sees the endless,🔽I have overcome birth, old age, and sorrow.
What is my old, ancient virtue and conduct?

analyzed: ācikkha me tam yam aham vijañña
translated: Explain that to me so that I may know.”
“The many people you gave water to,
Who were thirsty, who had come to the hot season,
That is your old, ancient virtue and conduct,
I remember it as if waking from sleep.
The people who were seized on the bank of the Eṇī River,
Who were being led away by the hunter,
That is your old, ancient virtue and conduct,
I remember it as if waking from sleep.
The boat that was seized in the current of the Ganges,
with the nāga named Luda, who was a human being,
you released him by force, by violence,
that ancient conduct of yours in regard to virtue and duty,
I remember it as if waking from sleep.

analyzed: kappaḥ ca te baddha caraḥ ahosi
translated: You were a slave named Kappa,
you respected the wise, the prudent, the noble,
that ancient conduct of yours in regard to virtue and duty,
I remember it as if waking from sleep.”
“Surely you know this life of mine,

analyzed: aññam pi jānāsi tathā hi buddhaḥ
translated: you know other things too, for you are the Buddha;
for you, with your radiant power,
shine and stand in the Brahmā world.”

analyzed: baka jātakam dasama  kukku vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: The Bakasutta is the tenth.
The first sub-chapter on the crow is finished.🔽The summary:
Varakaṇṇika, cāpavaro, sutano,

analyzed: atha gijjha sa rohita maccha varaḥ
translated: then the vulture, sarohitamacchavaro,
then the leaf, senaka, yācanako,

analyzed: atha veri sa brahma bakena dasāti
translated: then the quarrel, sabrahmabakena, dasa.
